ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: This is a GREAT class. Fantastic syllabus, fantastic professor, and a really engaging topic. Be prepared to have your views on all matters justice-related challenged and changed.

This is a quite remarkable course. Anyone looking for a truly challenging, strongly theoretically grounded WGSS course should take this class. The readings, though difficult (yes, there is a LOT of Rawls on the syllabus) is excellent, and Professor Fischel has really wonderful insight into it. There's a lot of reading, one presentation with a partner, a short (2 pg) reading response, and a long final paper with a volunteer component. In short: not a class for the faint of heart, but if you're committed to really learning then this is the class for you. A+.

If you're interested in the ethical and political ins-and-outs of social justice and human rights, take this course. There is a significant amount of reading, but aside from coming to class every week prepared for the conversation (and Joe is a very good discussion leader), there aren't many assignments. This means that there's little busy work, but the assignments that you do - including a cool volunteer project and a 15-20 page paper regarding it - are meaningful and require you to engage really deeply with the material and discussions. Everyone also does presentations in pairs to link the theory to real-life issues.

This had a lot of potential as a course, but was a fairly frustrating experience. Professor Fischel is awesome but is still coming into his own as a discussion leader/had some difficulty figuring out how to make the two-hour seminar the most productive. I felt like there wasn't really enough direction on all of the assignments, and like the class presentations felt so superfluous in a seminar when we had a difficult enough of a time getting through the material. I would recommend taking this class if it were revamped to focus on undergraduates more, and for students who are willing to sit through a fairly frustrating seminar for the chance to meet Fischel (who is great one-on-one) and read some pretty great articles and books.

Very interesting readings, definitely take it if you are interested in political theory an/or sexuality studies. You're not going to get this kind of recognition theorizing in the political science department so its a rather unique course offering. The final social-justice volunteering project is also really innovative and for that reason alone I would highly recommend the class. Just watch out for annoying WGSS majors who don't know when to shut up.
